posts.name: Sky Captain
posts.cooked:
Is there a way to read the pressure from the Rev Pneumatics Hub?  Can I get it directly through there, or do I need a separate sensor plugged into the analog rail on the Rio?  It seems moderately wasteful to need 2 of them.

It seems like the PH knows the voltage on the analog sensor, is there a call to read that voltage, then do a little math to convert that voltage to pressure?

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
You can use the getPressure() method of the PneumaticHub class.

If your pressure sensor is plugged into channel 0:

posts.name: Sky Captain
posts.cooked: Awesome, thanks. Where is the api for the rev hardware?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: For the PDH and PH, they’re part of WPILib. PneumaticHub (WPILib API 2022.1.1)

posts.name: Sky Captain
posts.cooked: So we have followed the assembly guide. We have a compressor, REV PH, analog pressure sensor and code that runs a solenoid (and all the appropriate tubing/gauges/air tanks etc.)  However the compressor is not automatically turning on.  The analog sensor is plugged into the #0 port on the PH.  We tested the system by using the standard digital pressure sensor and the compressor worked.  We are able to get an accurate pressure reading from the analog sensor, so we know it is working.  I’m not sure what else we are missing.

link_counts.title: REV PH not turning on compressor

posts.name: Sky Captain
posts.cooked: Nope, didn’t know that was a thing.  I will have our software team try that out.

posts.name: Debbie Bernier
Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: Are you measuring the pressure before or after the regulator?

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: What does getPressure return? Compressor (WPILib API 2022.2.1)

posts.name: Debbie Bernier
posts.cooked: getPressure was what I was reading (I put a widget on shuffleboard to see it). I also looked at the bot and at the time, both pressure gauges (before and after the regulator) were hovering around 60ish.    The getPressure returned value seemed to work correctly. We did check several times to see if it matched what the gauge said.

posts.name: dyanoshak
posts.cooked:
We haven’t been able to recreate what you’re seeing, but we’re going to need some more information.

Please send support@revroboticts.com an email so that we can start collecting more information, recreate what you’re seeing, and get you back up and running.

posts.name: Jimmy Mish
Debbie Bernier
posts.cooked:
Yes the pressure sensor is plumbed prior to the regulator.

The compressor is turning off at a value somewhere between 45-60 PSI regardless of the min/max values we provide to enableCompressorAnalog.  We tried min=115 and max=120 and it still shuts off early.

Our pneumatic hub is powered with 12 volts from position 22 on the rev PDH. The  picture of how to wire the hub in the REV documentation here: https://docs.revrobotics.com/rev-11-1852/pneumatic-hub-getting-started/wiring-the-pneumatic-hub shows the hub plugged into the switchable channel.

Is that necessary?  There’s no reason to turn off the hub so there’s no reason to have it switchable.

by the way, we can run the compressor manually and fill the tank to 120 psi.  The rev pressure sensor reads 120 when it’s done manually.

@dyanoshak thanks for responding. I’ll send an email.

posts.name: dyanoshak
posts.cooked:
crazycats:

shows the hub plugged into the switchable channel.

This is a mistake in the diagram. We’re working on fixing it. Connect it to any of the other low-current channels.

We’ll look out for your email.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
crazycats:

The picture of how to wire the hub in the REV documentation here: https://docs.revrobotics.com/rev-11-1852/pneumatic-hub-getting-started/wiring-the-pneumatic-hub shows the hub plugged into the switchable channel.

Is that necessary? There’s no reason to turn off the hub so there’s no reason to have it switchable.

Since Team Update 01, R503B.c says this is not legal.  The switchable circuit many only be used for non-actuator CUSTOM CIRCUITS.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: If I had a spare port 1-20, I’d do it with a 20 amp breaker.
